sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The Mousetweaks application provides mouse accessibility enhancements for the GNOME Desktop. Indeed, it offers the following new pointer functions to the user:

listitem.para: The possibility to perform a right click by holding the left mousebutton pressed while keeping the pointer motionless.
The possibility to perform the various clicks without pressing any hardware button.
The possibility to lock the pointer in a determined area of the panel until the user releases it by a predefined keystroke or mouse button.

sect2.title: Starting the pointer capture feature
sect2.para: As the pointer capture applet comes in the from of a panel applet, its starting method has to follow the rules dictated by the GNOME panel. Thus, to start the pointer capture feature, you only have to install it on the panel and it will automatically run, regardless of the state of the other features of Mousetweaks.

In order to add it to the panel, proceed as you do with any panel applet: right click on the panel to open its contextual menu, choose Add to Panel, and you will get the window showing all the applets that can be installed on the GNOME panel.
Picture showing the Pointer Capture applet in the Add to Panel window
By double clicking on the Pointer Capture item in the Add to Panel window, the pointer capture applet will be added to the panel, and it will be working until removed.

sect1.title: Description of the features
sect1.para:
The Mousetweaks application offers three new pointer features to the user. These are:
The manual assumes a right-handed user: consequently, left mouse button indicates the primary mouse button and right mouse button indicates the secondary mouse button. Of course, for a left-handed user that has enabled the corresponding option in the Mouse control panel, the terms left and right have to be exchanged.

sect2.title: Right clicking with the left button
sect2.para: When the user activates this feature, he will be able to perform right clicks by using the left mouse button. This is especially useful for users that have only one mouse button at their disposal.

sect3.title: How does it work?
sect3.para: When this feature is enabled, mousetweaks performs a right click at the location of the pointer, if the user keeps the left mouse button pressed without moving the pointer for a determined time.
How long the user has to hold the left mouse button pressed is determined by the slider in the control panel of mousetweaks with the title:

textobject.para: Picture showing the slider to set how long to hold the left button for the right click to be triggered

sect3.title: Differences to the normal right button click
sect3.para: As Mousetweaks is not able to discard the left mouse button down gesture from the left button press of the user, it issues a left click before issuing the right click. In other words, each right click performed by this feature of mousetweaks is immediately preceded by a left click, and this makes it behave a bit differently to the normal right click performed by the right mouse button. For example:

listitem.para: It is not possible to perform a right click on multiple items because the left click issued before the right click deselects the items.

When this type of right click is performed on the trash icon on the panel, not only does the contextual menu appear, but the trash folder does also open. (The former is caused by the right click, the latter by the left click preceding the right click.)

note.para: It is not possible to provide a list of all diverging behaviours, because it depends on the reaction of the application receiving the right click preceded by a left click.

sect3.para: Some users may also be surprised by the behaviour caused by the fact, that it is not possible to perform a long motionless left click and hold, without also doing a right click. For example:

listitem.para: When doing a motionless left click and hold on the arrow of a scrollbar, the scrollbar jumps to the bottom after some time. This is in fact the normal behaviour of a right click on an arrow of a scrollbar.

tip.para: To work around this behaviour, simply move the pointer immediately after pressing the mouse button. This way Mousetweaks does not issue the right click.

sect2.title: Clicking without the use of any hardware button
sect2.para: By activating this feature, users will be able to perform left clicks, double clicks, drag clicks and right clicks without having to press any mouse button.

note.para: When the buttonless click is active, the mouse buttons remain functional and it is still possible to click with the mouse buttons.

sect3.title: Click trigger and click type choice
sect3.para: The user can choose between two methods to trigger the clicks: by time or by gesture. There are two radio buttons for this purpose in the control panel of Mousetweaks.

textobject.para: Picture showing the radio buttons to select trigger method

sect3.para: To select the trigger method, the user only needs to click on the radio button that corresponds to his desired trigger method.

sect4.title: Trigger by time
sect4.para: In the trigger by time method, the Mousetweaks application automatically performs the click after the pointer has been motionless for a determined time.
sect4.remark: See Time settings for buttonless clicks for more information about how to set the time lapse that the pointer has to be motionless before performing the click.
sect4.para: The type of click performed depends on the selection in the click type window or click type applet. Have a look at the following picture to see the click type window and the click type applet:

textobject.para: Picture showing the click type window
Picture showing the click type applet at the right of the menus

sect4.para: To display the click type window on the screen, the user has to put a checkmark in the corresponding checkbox in the control panel of Mousetweaks.

To display the click type applet on the GNOME panel, please follow the procedure you have to use in order to add any applet to the GNOME panel. If you do not know how to add an applet to the panel, please have a look at Starting the pointer capture feature.
The click type window and the click type applet can be used simultaneously or each on its own.

tip.para: The click type applet is especially interesting for people that do not want to cover their desktop with the click type window.

sect4.title: Trigger by gesture
sect4.para: In the trigger by gesture method, the shape of the pointer changes to the gesture shape after being motionless for a determined time.
sect4.remark: See Time settings for buttonless clicks for more information about how to set the time lapse that the pointer has to be motionless before its shape changes to the gesture shape.
sect4.para: If the user moves the pointer while it is showing the gesture shape, a click is performed. Moreover, the type of click performed depends on the direction that the user moved the pointer.
If the user does not move the pointer while it is showing the gesture shape, its shape returns to the normal pointer shape and the user can again move the pointer without a click being performed.
There is a section in the control panel of Mousetweaks for the user to map click type to movement direction:

textobject.para: Picture showing the configuration options to map click type to movement direction

sect4.para: By using the popup menus, the user can set what direction he wants to correspond to what click type. There is also a Disabled menu item in each popup, so that user can disable the click types that he does not want to be performed automatically. This is especially interesting for users that have problems only with certain click types.

sect3.title: Time settings for buttonless clicks
sect3.para: When using the buttonless click feature, the pointer has to stay motionless for a determined time before a click is automatically performed or before the pointer changes its shape to the gesture shape. The control panel of Mousetweaks offers the following slider to set the time to wait before a click is triggered:

textobject.para: Picture showing the slider to set how long the pointer has to be motionless

sect3.para: By moving the Time to Wait slider, the user can tell Mousetweaks how long the pointer has to be motionless before a click is automatically performed or before the pointer changes its shape to the gesture shape.

note.para: This function only works in the context of the buttonless click.

sect3.title: Movement tolerance for buttonless clicks
sect3.para: When using the buttonless click feature, the pointer has to stay motionless for a determined time before a click is automatically performed or before the pointer changes its shape to the gesture shape. For people who have problems to keep the pointer motionless for a determined time lapse, there is a slider in the control panel of Mousetweaks to make it ignore small pointer movements.

textobject.para: Picture showing the slider to set the amount of pointer movement to ignore

sect3.para: By moving this slider, the user can indicate to Mousetweaks what maximum movement size it has to consider as motionless.

note.para: This function only works in the context of the buttonless click.

sect2.title: Locking the pointer
sect2.para: There are people that have to use their pointing device not only for the computer. These people would welcome a way to lock the pointer into an area of the screen, so that they can use their pointing device for other tasks. The Mousetweaks application ships with an applet called Pointer Capture that creates an area on the panel into which the user can lock the pointer until he releases it in a determined way.
sect2.remark: Have a look at Starting the pointer capture feature for instructions about how to install and remove it from the GNOME panel.

textobject.para: Picture showing the pointer capture area (green) with its contextual menu
Picture of the pointer capture area when the pointer has been captured

sect2.para: By choosing Preferences in the contextual menu of the pointer capture applet, the user gets a window with the options of the pointer capture applet:

textobject.para: Picture showing the preferences of the pointer capture applet

sect2.para: The preferences window of the pointer capture applet has three sections:

listitem.para: In the Capture Pointer section, the user can specify under what circumstances the pointer gets captured when it moves into the capture area. For example: if the control modifier is checked, the pointer gets captured when it is over the capture area and the user presses the Control modifier key. If no modifier is checked and the mouse button is set to 0, the pointer only has to move into the capture area to get locked.
It is also possible to specify a combination of modifiers and mouse button.
In the Release Pointer section, the user can specify what modifier or mouse button releases the pointer.
It is also possible to specify a combination of modifiers and mouse button.
In the Size of Capture Area section, the user can specify the width of the capture area on the GNOME panel.
